verses.text: His foundation is in the holy mountains.
verses.comment: The Psalm opens by declaring the Lord's chosen foundation set upon the holy mountains, a clear reference to Zion/Jerusalem. Many Fathers see a type here for the Church built on the 'rock' (cf. Matt 16:18). The mountains, in Catholic thought, also allude to the saints and apostles as 'foundations' (Eph 2:20).

verses.text: The LORD loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwelling places of Jacob.
verses.comment: Zion, often referring spiritually to the Church and ultimately fulfilled in Christ (Heb 12:22), is deeply loved by God. The preference for 'gates of Zion' echoes the Catholic reverence for the Church as the true spiritual home (cf. 1 Tim 3:15).

verses.text: Glorious things are spoken of you, O city of God. Selah.
verses.comment: Prophetic voices acclaim Jerusalem, yet this points forward to the heavenly Jerusalem, the dwelling of God with men (Rev 21:2-3). The Catholic tradition connects such glorification to Mary as 'city of God' in a mystical sense, just as she is called the Ark (cf. Luke 1:43, Rev 11:19–12:1).

verses.text: I will record Rahab and Babylon among those who know me; behold, Philistia and Tyre, with Cush—this one was born there.
verses.comment: The Psalmist proclaims salvation for former enemies; Gentile nations are counted as citizens of Zion. This anticipates the inclusion of all nations in Christ’s Church (Eph 2:13-19), and echoes the Catholic emphasis on universality ('catholic' means universal).

verses.text: And of Zion it shall be said, 'This one and that one were born in her'; for the Most High himself establishes her.
verses.comment: Zion’s spiritual motherhood is noted—she gives birth to many people. The Fathers saw in this the Church’s role in spiritual rebirth through baptism, a key sacrament for entering the Church (John 3:5; 1 Pet 1:23).

verses.text: The LORD records, as he registers the peoples, 'This one was born there.' Selah.
verses.comment: God himself enrolls the nations as citizens—a parallel to the Book of Life (Rev 21:27). The Catholic doctrine sees in baptism the means by which names are written in heaven. This belongs to the communal, sacramental life of the Church.

verses.text: Singers and dancers alike say, 'All my springs are in you.'
verses.comment: 'Springs' imply sources of life and grace. In Catholic thought, the Church is the fountain of the sacraments and spiritual life. Jesus’ words (John 7:38) about 'rivers of living water' flow most deeply in the Church. The joy and beauty in worship are a hallmark both of earthly Zion and the new covenant community.
